caption: A rather sombre experience when I stopped at this Square Jules Ferry around Saint Ambroise area and Canal Saint Martin. There is a Memorial site that marks the spot where so many lives were taken on November 13th 2015! I was here in 2024 and still feel emotionally touched. This is actually a long public park with playgrounds for children and surrounded on both sides by beautiful Avenues filled with shops, cafÃ©s and restaurants. There's street parking available and public lavatory dotted throughout the park. This is a lovely Park area and despite the tragedy I feel people are slowly getting on with their lives. This park also complete with public toilets and many green benches for people to rest and enjoy their day.

This isnâ€™t really a park for dogs, itâ€™s more of a small fenced in area around a waterway with some foliage. Dogs are allowed on leash, but not off. However, if you just wanted to sit in a bench away from the street and enjoy a takeaway coffee, etc, itâ€™s nice for a few minutes.
Beautiful park, with friday open market. Lots of fresh French produce, got a fresh homemade brut apple cider for less than 5 euros. Dog park as well for those with furry pals. Awesome place to run.

The place is nice, but the state of use is not ideal. In the morning and evening, it is closed, which means you have to walk close to the road next to it, with very little space for pedestrians, joggers and people with disabilities.

Linear garden with trees, it is integrated into the Richard Lenoir promenade. This square is one of the four gardens that make up the Richard-Lenoir promenade, built on a vault since Haussmann, whose recent developments have been designed to recall the existence of the Saint-Martin canal under the cobblestones. The square is named after Jules Ferry, French politician, author of the laws of the Third Republic which made secular education and teaching compulsory.

The Richard Lenoir promenade is made up of the Richard-Lenoir, BrÃ©guet-Sabin, May Picqueray and (here) Jules Ferry squares, above the covered part of the Saint-Martin canal. Dug in 1826, the canal was covered by Boulevard Richard-Lenoir in 1860, from Avenue de la RÃ©publique to the Bastille (Port de l'Arsenal): for this it was necessary to lower its bed to make possible the boat traffic. We see in the squares, like here at Square Jules Ferry, the ventilation openings (also skylights) piercing the vaults of the buried canal: this allows those who have had the experience of this underground navigation to imagine the city in the -above ! Square Jules Ferry, like the others, is an island of freshness and (relative) calm. The atmosphere is family and serene, depending on the days of the week and times of day, of course. Ultimately, it should lose its status as a square to become an element of "pedestrian and plant continuity" removing the current gates and hedges.
What is this square that is closing? At 5 p.m. - and turns the boulevard into a no ho zone.
